Introduction

Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is a rapid arrhythmia caused by abnormal electrical activity that originates in the ventricles.  Compared with supraventricular tachycardia (described in a separate article), VT is far more likely to cause hemodynamic collapse and sudden cardiac arrest; VT and ventricular fibrillation account for nearly all arrhythmia-related sudden cardiac deaths (SCDs).  VT requires prompt recognition and management to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Types and pathophysiology

VT typically occurs paroxysmally, with abrupt onset and offset.

Sustained vs nonsustained VT

The arrhythmia is considered nonsustained or sustained based on duration:

  • Nonsustained VT is defined as â‰¥3 consecutive ventricular beats with a rate >100/min and with spontaneous return to the baseline rhythm within 30 seconds.
  • Sustained VT is VT lasting â‰¥30 seconds or causing hemodynamic collapse (ie, syncope or cardiac arrest) within 30 seconds.

Monomorphic vs polymorphic VT

VT is further classified based on the nature of the underlying conduction disturbance:

  • Monomorphic VT is the most common type of VT.  It results from a single ectopic electrical focus in the right or left ventricle that creates a high frequency of spontaneous depolarization.  It usually occurs due to a small reentrant circuit (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ) that develops in an area of scarred or fibrosed myocardium (eg, previously infarcted myocardium).  Monomorphic VT is most commonly seen in patients with ischemic heart disease and/or heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
  • Polymorphic VT results from abnormal electrical activity that originates from multiple locations in the ventricles.  It most commonly occurs in the setting of a prolonged QT interval and in such instances is known as torsades de pointes (TdP).  Less commonly, polymorphic VT can develop due to acute myocardial ischemia or congenital channelopathies (eg, Brugada syndrome, catecholaminergic polymorphic VT).

In VT, there is usually atrioventricular dissociation, with a separate rhythm in the atria (usually a normal rhythm originating in the sinus node) that typically does not communicate with the abnormal rhythm originating in the ventricles (causing a wide-complex tachycardia).  The abnormal electrical activity originating in the ventricles becomes the primary pacemaker for the ventricles.

VT is far more likely than supraventricular tachycardia to cause hemodynamic collapse for 2 major reasons:

  • The electrical impulses stimulating ventricular contraction are not slowed by the atrioventricular node, so very high ventricular rates (eg, ~250/min) can develop and markedly impair diastolic filling.
  • Ventricular contractions stimulated by impulses originating in the ventricles are much less coordinated than those stimulated via the normal His-Purkinje system.  This can result in impaired systolic function during VT.

Ventricular fibrillation (VF) describes markedly chaotic ventricular activity that usually results from degeneration of sustained VT.  It is a nonperfusing rhythm that invariably causes cardiac arrest.

Risk factors

Monomorphic VT

  • Ischemic heart disease:  Ischemic heart disease is the strongest risk factor for VT.  Scar tissue from a prior myocardial infarction provides a nidus for reentrant circuit development and the generation of ectopic electrical foci in the ventricles.  VT degenerating to VF is the most common cause of death during acute myocardial infarction.
  • Chronic HFrEF:  The risk of VT is increased in patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) <30%-35%, regardless of the underlying cause.  Areas of myocardial fibrosis likely serve as sources for ectopic electrical foci.
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):  The risk of VT is increased in some patients with HCM, likely due to the myocardial disarray and microvascular dysfunction associated with the disease.
  • Infiltrative cardiac diseases:  Infiltrative diseases (eg, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis) disrupt ventricular conduction and increase the risk for VT.
  • Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome:  Preexcited atrial fibrillation degenerating into VF (often without preceding VT) is the most common cause of SCD in patients with WPW syndrome.
  • Other congenital heart diseases causing disrupted ventricular conduction (eg, arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy) or exertional ischemia (eg, anomalous origin of a coronary artery) also increase the risk of VT and VF.

Polymorphic VT

  • Long QT syndrome can be congenital or acquired (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ).  The prolonged QT interval creates an extended vulnerable period during which a premature beat can trigger the abnormal ventricular activity of TdP.
  • Brugada syndrome is a rare congenital channelopathy that affects sodium channels in the right ventricle and predisposes to polymorphic VT.
  • Catecholaminergic polymorphic VT is a rare congenital channelopathy that usually involves disrupted calcium channels and predisposes to polymorphic VT.

Clinical presentation

  • Nonsustained VT is usually asymptomatic, although palpitations are present in some cases.
  • Sustained VT often leads to abrupt hemodynamic collapse with minimal preceding symptoms.  The hemodynamic collapse causes loss of consciousness (LOC) that can present as either syncope or sudden cardiac arrest:
    • Syncope occurs when sustained VT causes an initial drop in cerebral perfusion with resulting LOC, but within 1-2 minutes the arrhythmia spontaneously resolves (or slows in rate) to allow a return of perfusion.
    • Sudden cardiac arrest occurs when there is not a prompt return of perfusion following LOC (and it progresses to SCD if the patient is not resuscitated).
  • Relatively slow sustained monomorphic VT (eg, rate <180/min) often does not cause LOC and may present with nonspecific findings (eg, dyspnea, pressure-like chest discomfort [anginal pain], lightheadedness, palpitations).  Rarely, relatively young and healthy patients with sustained VT can remain mostly asymptomatic for an extended period (eg, hours or days).  Relatively older patients with substantial comorbidities (eg, ischemic heart disease, heart failure) are more likely to experience symptoms and abrupt hemodynamic collapse.
  • TdP often occurs in brief episodes that spontaneously resolve.  It is a disorganized and poorly perfusing rhythm that, when sustained, usually leads to rapid hemodynamic collapse.  Other types of polymorphic VT also tend to lead to hemodynamic collapse more quickly than does monomorphic VT. 

Physical examination

Palpation of the radial or carotid pulse reveals a rapid rate.  The rhythm can be regular or irregular depending on the type of VT present.  Patients may quickly develop an absent pulse (sudden cardiac arrest due to pulseless VT).

The atrioventricular dissociation of VT can create intermittent cannon A waves in the jugular venous pulse waveform (

figure 1
).  These are caused by atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve; the atria and ventricles are driven by separate rhythms that are out of sync, sometimes contracting simultaneously.

ECG

  • Nonsustained VT (
    figure 2
    ) features a burst of â‰¥3 ventricular beats (wide QRS complex) at a rate >100/min (QRS complexes occur <3 large boxes apart (
    figure 3
    )).  In monomorphic nonsustained VT, the rhythm is regular.
  • Sustained VT
    • Sustained monomorphic VT (
      figure 4
      ) shows wide QRS complexes (>120 msec) with a rapid rate and regular R-R intervals.  The QRS complexes are all similar in size and shape.  P waves (representing the ongoing atrial rhythm) are usually obscured by the QRS complexes but may be occasionally visible.
    • Sustained polymorphic VT features wide QRS complexes (>120 msec) with a rapid rate and irregular rhythm.  The QRS complexes vary in size and shape.  As with monomorphic VT, P waves are usually obscured.  TdP (
      figure 5
      ) demonstrates a characteristic twisting of the peaks pattern in which the QRS amplitude varies cyclically.
  • VF (
    figure 6
    ) shows chaotic electrical activity with an absence of organized QRS complexes.

Diagnosis

The diagnosis of VT should be suspected based on clinical presentation and is confirmed by ECG or cardiac rhythm monitoring.

Characteristic ECG findings created by the presence of separate rhythms in the atria and ventricles can help confirm the diagnosis of VT.  Occasionally, the impulse from the atrial rhythm passes through the atrioventricular node to partially or fully depolarize the ventricles, creating one of the following 2 characteristic beats (

figure 7
):

Fusion beat

  • If the ventricles are depolarized partially by this atrial rhythm and partially by the ventricular rhythm, a fusion beat with a QRS complex of intermediate width is created.

Capture beat

  • If the ventricles are depolarized fully by the atrial rhythm, a normal-appearing beat with a narrow QRS complex called a capture beat is created.

The presence of occasional fusion or capture beats within wide-complex tachycardia verifies the presence of 2 separate rhythms (one in the atria and one in the ventricles) and confirms VT.

Differential diagnosis

Monomorphic vs polymorphic VT

Monomorphic VT is differentiated from polymorphic VT by monomorphic VT's regular R-R intervals (rather than irregular) and QRS complexes of a uniform size and shape (rather than multiform).

Supraventricular tachycardia

Supraventricular tachycardia (eg, atrial flutter, atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia) usually demonstrates narrow QRS complexes and VT characteristically creates wide QRS complexes; therefore, tachycardia with wide QRS complexes usually represents a form of VT.  However, occasionally, supraventricular tachycardia with a conduction abnormality (with aberrancy) can create wide QRS complexes and mimic the appearance of VT:

  • Supraventricular tachycardia with bundle branch block can demonstrate wide QRS complexes and can appear similar to sustained VT.  Supraventricular tachycardia does not cause fusion or capture beats (because a single rhythm is present and drives both atrial and ventricular conduction); therefore, the presence of occasional fusion or capture beats confirms the diagnosis of VT.
  • Preexcited atrial fibrillation can occur in the setting of an accessory pathway that directly connects the atria and the ventricles (ie, in patients with WPW syndrome) (
    figure 8
    ).  It demonstrates wide QRS complexes that can mimic sustained VT, but there is typically extensive variability in beat-to-beat QRS morphology in preexcited atrial fibrillation.  In addition, the presence of occasional fusion or capture beats is not expected with preexcited atrial fibrillation.

Electronic pacemaker

Electronic ventricular pacemakers (

figure 9
) directly stimulate the right ventricular myocardium without the impulse traveling through the His-Purkinje system; therefore, the QRS morphology is wide (
figure 10
) and mimics that of a left bundle branch block.  A pacemaker-mediated tachycardia can appear similar to VT but will demonstrate pacemaker spikes (ie, pacemaker activation) just before each QRS complex.  VT, which is driven by an ectopic rhythm, will not demonstrate pacemaker spikes before each QRS complex.

Management

Nonsustained VT

Nonsustained VT is frequently recognized on continuous telemetry monitoring in hospitalized patients with underlying risk factors (eg, ischemic heart disease, heart failure) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  Management focuses on addressing precipitating factors to reduce the likelihood of the development of sustained VT and includes:

  • Identification and correction of electrolyte abnormalities (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia)
  • Minimization of hypoxemia and other contributors to myocardial ischemia
  • A beta blocker (eg, metoprolol) may be initiated (or the dose increased) to reduce myocardial oxygen demand and sympathetic tone

Sustained VT

The management of sustained VT follows the wide QRS complex side of the Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS) guideline flowchart for management of tachycardia (

figure 11
).

Sustained monomorphic VT

Patients with evidence of hemodynamic instability (eg, hypotension, angina, confusion) should undergo immediate synchronized cardioversion.  Synchronized electrical cardioversion delivers a low-voltage electrical shock that is timed (synchronized) to the R wave of the QRS complex to restore normal rhythm.  Synchronization is accomplished by pressing the "sync" button on the defibrillator.

  • Note that a pulseless patient with sustained VT (or VF) is in cardiac arrest and should receive immediate cardiopulmonary resuscitation with electrical defibrillation, in which a higher-voltage electrical shock is delivered without synchronization (
    figure 12
    ).

Patients with sustained monomorphic VT who are hemodynamically stable can receive antiarrhythmic therapy to attempt pharmacologic cardioversion to sinus rhythm.  Intravenous amiodarone is usually the preferred agent.  Other agents, including procainamide, sotalol, and lidocaine, can also be used.  Impending hemodynamic collapse should be assumed in hemodynamically stable patients and a cardiac monitor with electrical cardioversion/defibrillation pads should be in place while attempting pharmacologic cardioversion.

Sustained polymorphic VT (other than TdP)

Forms of sustained polymorphic VT other than TdP are treated similarly to sustained monomorphic VT.

Torsades de pointes

TdP requires special management consideration:

  • Patients with TdP who are conscious but have evidence of hemodynamic instability should receive immediate electrical defibrillation (ie, unsynchronized cardioversion).  Synchronized cardioversion is not appropriate for TdP because the automatic defibrillator is unable to detect the disorganized QRS complexes (ie, cannot sync) and cannot deliver a synchronized shock.
  • Patients with TdP who are hemodynamically stable should receive intravenous magnesium sulfate as first-line therapy.  This therapy is effective at stabilizing ventricular electrical activity and curtailing TdP even in patients with normal serum magnesium levels.  Additional management can include interventions to increase heart rate (eg, temporary electronic pacing), which shortens the QT interval and reduces the risk of TdP redeveloping.

Primary and secondary prevention of VT with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement

An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) should be placed in certain patients due to the risk of VT.  An ICD is programmed to detect life-threatening arrythmias (eg, VT) and deliver electric shocks to terminate them.

Primary prevention is indicated in patients who are at high risk of SCD from sustained VT (but who have not previously had VT).  This includes those with:

  • Prior myocardial infarction and LVEF â‰¤30%
  • Symptomatic heart failure with LVEF â‰¤35%

Secondary prevention is indicated for the following:

  • Prior VT/VF cardiac arrest
  • Prior sustained VT that does not have a reversible cause

Chronic suppression of VT

  • Beta blockers (eg, metoprolol) reduce ventricular automaticity and can be helpful in the chronic suppression of VT.  Most patients with monomorphic VT already have an underlying indication for beta blocker therapy (eg, ischemic heart disease, HFrEF).
  • Chronic antiarrhythmic therapy (eg, amiodarone) is sometimes used to help suppress VT in patients with a history of the arrhythmia.
  • In some patients with monomorphic VT, catheter ablation can be helpful by disrupting the ectopic reentrant circuit.

Complications

  • Sudden cardiac arrest can occur in the form of pulseless VT or VT that degenerates into VF.
  • VT storm refers to the recurrence of multiple episodes of VT (or VF) within 24 hours and is associated with high mortality.

Prognosis

In general, the prognosis in patients with sustained VT is poor because VT is usually a manifestation of advanced, life-limiting heart disease, and the initial episode of sustained VT is potentially fatal.  However, appropriate management (eg, ICD placement) can help reduce mortality.  Relatively young and healthy patients who experience VT due to a reversible or manageable cause (eg, QT prolongation, WPW syndrome) can have an excellent prognosis after surviving an episode of sustained VT.

Summary

Ventricular tachycardia is a rapid arrhythmia caused by abnormal electrical activity that originates in the ventricles.  Along with ventricular fibrillation, it accounts for the vast majority of arrhythmia-related sudden cardiac deaths.  Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia is the most common type of ventricular tachycardia and usually occurs in patients with ischemic heart disease, heart failure, or other underlying cardiac disease (eg, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy).  Torsades de pointes is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that can occur in the setting of a prolonged QT interval.  Ventricular tachycardia requires prompt recognition and management to prevent sudden cardiac arrest and reduce the risk of sudden cardiac death.
